Weekly State of the Market - Cross-Asset Overview (2025-09-16)

Executive Summary

The latest Commitments of Traders (COT) data for the week ending September 16, 2025, reveals a market dominated by extreme speculative positioning in energy and equities, contrasted with deepening bearish conviction in fixed income and currencies. Crude Oil and the S&P 500 show strong, near-extreme bullish sentiment, signaling potential upside but also heightened reversal risk. Conversely, Natural Gas, US 10-Year T-Notes, and EUR/USD reflect persistent and growing bearish speculative bets.

Key Opportunities

  • Crude Oil Sustained Upside: Extreme speculative net-longs and continued buying suggest strong momentum, potentially driving prices higher in the short term.
  • S&P 500 Bullish Momentum: Non-commercials remain significantly net-long, signaling conviction for further equity market gains.
  • Natural Gas Short Covering: A notable reduction in speculative short positions, despite being net-short, sets the stage for a potential short squeeze on positive catalysts.

Key Risks

  • Crude Oil Reversal Potential: Speculative net-long positioning is at an extreme (COT Index: 88.54), indicating a high risk of a sharp correction should sentiment shift or profit-taking accelerate.
  • US 10-Year T-Note Bearish Persistency: Increasing speculative net-shorts suggest continued downside pressure on bond prices (upside pressure on yields).
  • EUR/USD Declining Conviction: Growing speculative short exposure and decreasing longs amplify downside risk for the currency pair.

Asset Class Summaries

CRUDE OIL, LIGHT SWEET

  • Speculators: Dominantly bullish with an extreme net-long position of 301,894 contracts, increasing by 18,700 WoW. Positioning is at a significant bullish extreme (COT Index: 88.54).
  • Commercials: Heavily net-short (-345,116 contracts), reflecting their traditional role as hedgers against price increases.
  • Implication: Strong speculative conviction fuels potential upside, but the extreme positioning flags considerable reversal risk.

NATURAL GAS

  • Speculators: Dominantly bearish with a net-short position of -218,631 contracts. Net shorts decreased by 6,400 WoW. Positioning remains bearish but less extreme (COT Index: 12.33).
  • Commercials: Significantly net-long (254,115 contracts), hedging against falling prices.
  • Implication: Persistent bearish sentiment, yet the reduction in speculative shorts hints at potential for short covering if momentum shifts.

S&P 500 STOCK INDEX

  • Speculators: Strongly bullish with a substantial net-long position of 98,750 contracts, increasing by 2,300 WoW. Positioning is bullish and nearing extreme (COT Index: 78.10).
  • Commercials: Net-short (-105,250 contracts), indicating hedging activity against upward market movements.
  • Implication: Firm speculative conviction supports further equity gains, but the high COT Index suggests caution is warranted.

US 10-YEAR T-NOTE

  • Speculators: Dominantly bearish with a net-short position of -201,340 contracts. Net shorts increased by 17,400 WoW. Positioning remains strongly bearish (COT Index: 25.15).
  • Commercials: Significantly net-long (198,800 contracts), hedging against declining bond prices (rising yields).
  • Implication: Strong and increasing speculative bearish conviction implies continued pressure for lower bond prices / higher yields.

EUR/USD

  • Speculators: Bearish with a net-short position of -65,300 contracts. Net shorts increased significantly by 10,800 WoW. Positioning is bearish (COT Index: 30.50).
  • Commercials: Net-long (58,100 contracts), hedging against further currency depreciation.
  • Implication: Weakening speculative conviction in the long side, combined with increasing shorts, points to further downside risk for EUR/USD.
